body.p: Blood vessels need an ability to constrict or dilate, and the extracellular matrix of most vessels is called the elastic laminae. The elastic laminae has a high concentration of the elastin protein. Elastin, when combined with other extracellular components helps blood vessels and other tissues, including skin, to return to their original shapes after dilation or is deformation. Elastin molecules are disorganized, entangled and crosslinked. When stretched, these fibers straighten out, but will recoil back to normal when force is released on the tissues.

Collagen is a stiff, filamentous extracellular protein found in most connective tissues. Collagen filaments are composed of twisted protofilaments, and protofilaments themselves are also twisted. Thus, collagen has ropelike qualities that provide stiffness. In blood vessels, collagen is found in the tunicia externa and provides stiffness to the blood vessel to prevent rupture. Arteries contain blood at higher pressure than veins so they have a thicker layer of collagen than veins.
